title: Tenth gen Giant TCR gets lighter, stiffer, more aero and hides cables
content:
Cyclist
Tenth gen Giant TCR gets lighter, stiffer, more aero and hides cables

Giant has revamped its TCR bike range, with a new frame design and construction methods that it says make the new bike over four watts faster than it’s predecessor. Around half of that comes from the frame and half from a new integrated cockpit. The TCR’s cables are finally hidden away in a similar manner to the brand’s Propel and Defy bikes, and the brand says the new platform is, of course, lighter and stiffer to boot.

The TCR will be available at three frame spec levels: Advanced SL, ridden by Jayco AlUla, Advanced Pro and Advanced. Prices range from £3,199 / $3,200 / €2,799 / AU$3,799 to £11,999 / $12,500 / €12,300.

Related Posts

Giant Revolt X Advanced Pro 0 review

The complete history of the Giant TCR

Giant Propel Advanced SL 0 review

Giant Defy Advanced SL 0 review

Tenth generation of the TCR

Giant claims that the new frame design and construction make this tenth generation of the TCR its lightest, stiffest and most aero yet.

Giant says that the components of the new TCR have been engineered to work together as a system and that the changes with the most effect on its performance have been at the front end of the bike.

This includes an updated fork design, with more aero legs and a new crown. Tyre clearance has been increased to 33mm. The fork has been engineered to work alongside the updated, more aero, down tube to deliver aero gains. 

The TCR’s compact geometry (TCR stands for Total Compact Road) was trendsetting when the bike was launched 28 years ago, as it lowered frame weight and increased stiffness over the horizontal top tube designs then current.

The last generation TCR had external cabling in the cockpit, but that’s disappeared in the Advanced SL and Advanced Pro specs of the new bike. They use the Giant Contact SLR or SL bars and Contact SLR/SL stem, as first seen on the current generation Giant Propel, with cables routed into the OverDrive Aero steerer.

Giant says that the design allows some extra cable and hose length, making it easier to add or remove spacers under the stem. The cables in the lower spec TCR Advanced bikes are semi-integrated, running externally under the stem, then into the headset top cap. 

As with Giant’s other road bikes, the top spec Advanced SL frameset comes with a seatmast. Giant says that this is more aero and reduces system weight by 40g over the separate aero carbon seatpost used in the Advanced Pro and Advanced frames.

Giant has continued its practice of offering wheels from its Cadex performance brand on its top spec builds, while mid-range bikes get Giant wheel/tyre systems. Both are delivered tubeless with Cadex or Giant 28mm tyres.

Top spec bikes get Cadex’s new Max 40 wheelsystem, which uses a hookless aero rim, carbon spokes, ceramic bearings and a ratchet freehub with 48 points of engagement for Cadex’s lightest ever build, with a claimed 1,249g wheelset weight.

Mid-spec bikes are equipped with a new Giant SLR 0 or 1 40 wheelsystem. The SLR 0 40 has a claimed weight of 1,339g and the SLR 1 40 1,443g, again both with a hookless rim profile.

There’s a new Cadex tyre on high spec bikes too. Called the Cadex Race GC, it has a low profile tread pattern and a 240tpi casing with fewer layers to increase suppleness and rolling efficiency, with a claimed 18 percent reduction in rolling resistance and a weight of 279g in 28mm width.

New construction techniques

Giant says that its new fabrication methods, using carbon fibre woven in its own factory, lower weight while adding stiffness to the new TCR Advanced SL frameset. It claims that most of the stiffness gains are from changes to the frame’s head tube, down tube and bottom bracket.

Giant has used a new, more precise cutting technique for its pre-preg, which has allowed it to reduce the number of pieces and hence lower weight. The front triangle is moulded as a single piece, which again lowers weight.

Alongside CFD modelling, Giant has taken the new TCR frame to the GST wind tunnel in Immenstadt, Germany, which has also been used by Canyon, Swissside and Hunt, among others, to test bikes and components.

It used a pedalling mannequin to verify the bike’s aero credentials, rather than the static mannequin more normally used, to better reflect real-world riding.  

The net result, Giant claims, is a 4.19 watt aero gain over the previous generation TCR at 40km/h, with 2.28 watts contributed by the new frame design.

New Giant TCR Advanced UK specs and prices

As is usual, Giant offers different specs across different geographies, so available models and their specs may differ for non-UK readers. The complete size range spreads from XS through to XL, but again not all frame sizes are available for all specs depending on location.

There’s a choice of Shimano and SRAM groupsets and the Advanced SL and Advanced Pro specs are equipped with power meters from Shimano, SRAM or Giant. 

All specs except the Advanced 1 and 2 have carbon wheels too, either with Cadex or Giant 28mm tyres. Lower specs have Giant 25mm tyres, which Giant says have an effective width of 28mm on its rims.

Euro prices and spec availability vary by country; we’ve shown prices in France.

TCR Advanced SL

TCR Advanced SL 0-DA

Frame/fork: Advanced SL Grade Composite
Groupset: Shimano Dura-Ace 52/36t, 11-34t with Shimano power meter
Wheels: Cadex 40 Max Disc
Tyres: Cadex Race GC Tubeless, 28mm
Handlebar: Giant Contact SLR
Stem: Giant Contact SLR Aerolight
Seatpost: Integrated with 25mm or 40mm masthead
Saddle: Cadex Amp one-piece
Price: £11,999 / $12,500 / €12,300 / AU$13,799
